message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Quantifying the local adaptive landscape of a nascent bacterial community
Paper Abstract: Abstract The fitness effects of all possible mutations available to an organism largely shape the dynamics of evolutionary adaptation. Yet, whether and how this adaptive landscape changes over evolutionary times, especially upon ecological diversification and changes in community composition, remains poorly understood. We sought to fill this gap by analyzing a stable community of two closely related ecotypes (“L” and “S”) shortly after they emerged within the E. coli Long-Term Evolution Experiment (LTEE). We engineered genome-wide barcoded transposon libraries to measure the invasion fitness effects of all possible gene knockouts in the coexisting strains as well as their ancestor, for many different, ecologically relevant conditions. We find consistent statistical patterns of fitness effect variation across both genetic background and community composition, despite the idiosyncratic behavior of individual knockouts. Additionally, fitness effects are correlated with evolutionary outcomes for a number of conditions, possibly revealing shifting patterns of adaptation. Together, our results reveal how ecological and epistatic effects combine to shape the adaptive landscape in a nascent ecological community.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I found comprehensive information about evolutionary adaptation. Here's what the search revealed:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Evolutionary adaptation is the dynamic evolutionary process of natural selection that fits organisms to their environment, enhancing their evolutionary fitness.(no content)It is the evolutionary process whereby populations of organisms become better able to live in a habitat or habitats.

## Types of Adaptations

Adaptive traits may be structural, behavioural or physiological. These include:

- **Structural adaptations**: Physical features of an organism, such as shape, body covering, armament, and internal organization.
- **Behavioral adaptations**: Inherited systems of behaviour, whether inherited in detail as instincts, or as a neuropsychological capacity for learning. Examples include searching for food, mating, and vocalizations.
- **Physiological adaptations**: Special functions such as making venom, secreting slime, and phototropism, but also involve more general functions such as growth and development, temperature regulation, ionic balance and other aspects of homeostasis.

## Key Distinction

Adaptation is primarily a process rather than a physical form or part of a body.(no content)Adaptation differs from flexibility, acclimatization, and learning, all of which are changes during life which are not inherited.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Epistasis genetics"

Links: [{"title":"Epistasis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistasis"},{"title":"Epistasis and functional genomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistasis_and_functional_genomics"},{"title":"Additive genetic effects - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Additive_genetic_effects"},{"title":"Labrador Retriever coat colour genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labrador_Retriever_coat_colour_genetics"},{"title":"Population genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_genetics"},{"title":"Polygene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygene"},{"title":"Hypostatic gene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypostatic_gene"},{"title":"Punnett square - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punnett_square"},{"title":"Association mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_mapping"},{"title":"Inclusive composite interval mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inclusive_composite_interval_mapping"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about epistasis in genetics:

## Definition

Epistasis refers to genetic interactions in which the mutation of one gene masks the phenotypic effects of a mutation at another locus. More specifically, the phenotypic and/or fitness effect of an allele at one locus depends on which alleles are present at other loci.

## Historical Background

The term was first used in 1907 by William Bateson and his collaborators Florence Durham and Muriel Wheldale Onslow.(no content)Understanding of epistasis has changed considerably through the history of genetics and so too has the use of the term.

## Types of Epistasis

When the double mutation has a fitter phenotype than expected from the effects of the two single mutations, it is referred to as positive epistasis. Positive epistasis between beneficial mutations generates greater improvements in function than expected.(no content)Conversely, when two mutations together lead to a less fit phenotype than expected from their effects when alone, it is called negative epistasis.

## Real-World Example

A classic example is found in Labrador Retrievers. These genes do not act independently of each other, and their interaction in affecting the trait of coat colour is used by biology textbooks to demonstrate the genetic principle of epistasis, where multiple genes react synergistically to affect a single trait.

## Functional Genomics Applications

Systematic analysis of these epistatic interactions can provide insight into the structure and function of genetic pathways.

Web search results for query: "Fitness evolution biology"

Links: [{"title":"Fitness landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_landscape"},{"title":"Fitness (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_(biology)"},{"title":"Inclusive fitness in humans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inclusive_fitness_in_humans"},{"title":"Evolutionary tradeoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_tradeoff"},{"title":"Survival of the fittest - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survival_of_the_fittest"},{"title":"Evolutionary landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_landscape"},{"title":"Selection coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selection_coefficient"},{"title":"Evolutionary invasion analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_invasion_analysis"},{"title":"Fecundity selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fecundity_selection"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of fitness in evolutionary biology:

## Definition of Fitness

In evolutionary biology, fitness is a quantitative representation of individual reproductive success and is equal to the average contribution to the gene pool of the next generation, made by the same individuals of the specified genotype or phenotype.(no content)The biological concept of fitness is defined as reproductive success, and in Darwinian terms, the phrase is best understood as "survival of the form that in successive generations will leave most copies of itself."

## Historical Development

J.B.S. Haldane was the first to quantify fitness, in terms of the modern evolutionary synthesis of Darwinism and Mendelian genetics starting with his 1924 paper A Mathematical Theory of Natural and Artificial Selection.(no content)The concept of inclusive fitness was introduced by W.D. Hamilton in 1964 in his paper on The Genetical Evolution of Social Behaviour.

## Fitness Landscapes

In evolutionary biology, fitness landscapes or adaptive landscapes are used to visualize the relationship between genotypes and reproductive success, and it is assumed that every genotype has a well-defined replication rate (often referred to as fitness).(no content)An evolving population typically climbs uphill in the fitness landscape, by a series of small genetic changes, until a local optimum is reached.

## Evolutionary Tradeoffs

Tradeoffs refer to the process through which a trait increases in fitness at the expense of decreased fitness in another trait. This is a fundamental concept showing how organisms cannot optimize all traits simultaneously.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about bacterial communities:

## Definition

A bacterial community (or microbial consortium) is two or more bacterial or microbial groups living symbiotically.

## Characteristics and Interactions

When a bacterial community — two or more interacting microorganisms — is involved, additive or synergistic results can be expected, in part because multiple species can perform a variety of tasks in an ecosystem like the plant root rhizosphere.(no content)In a community, microorganisms will interact on a large scale to allow for the persistence of the population, which will thereby increase their own fitness.

## Common Environments

In nature, many organisms live in communities (e.g., biofilms) that may allow for increased supply of nutrients and protection from environmental stresses.(no content)Consortia are commonly found in humans, with the predominant examples being the skin consortium and the intestinal consortium which provide protection and aid in human nutrition.

## Human Microbiome

The Human Microbiome Project found that individuals host thousands of bacterial types, with different body sites having their own distinctive communities, with skin and vaginal sites showing smaller diversity than the mouth and gut, which show the greatest richness.

## Industrial and Environmental Applications

Significant achievements have been made with single strains, but focus is now going toward the use of bacterial consortia owing to their functional stability and efficiency.

Here are the search results for Escherichia coli:

## Overview

Escherichia coli is a gram-negative, facultative anaerobic, rod-shaped, coliform bacterium of the genus Escherichia that is commonly found in the lower intestine of warm-blooded organisms.

## Laboratory and Research

E. coli K-12 and E. coli B strains are the most frequently used varieties for laboratory purposes.(no content)E. coli is the most widely studied prokaryotic model organism, and an important species in the fields of biotechnology and microbiology, where it has served as the host organism for the majority of work with recombinant DNA.

## Genome

The first complete DNA sequence of an E. coli genome (laboratory strain K-12 derivative MG1655) was published in 1997. It is a circular DNA molecule 4.6 million base pairs in length, containing 4288 annotated protein-coding genes (organized into 2584 operons), seven ribosomal RNA (rRNA) operons, and 86 transfer RNA (tRNA) genes.

## Pathogenic Strains

While most E. coli strains are harmless, some can cause disease:

- More virulent strains, such as O157:H7, cause serious illness or death in the elderly, the very young, or the immunocompromised.
- E. coli O157:H7 was first recognized as a human pathogen following a 1982 hemorrhagic colitis outbreak in Oregon and Michigan.
- Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) is a pathotype of Escherichia coli that produces enterotoxins and colonizes the small intestine; it is a major bacterial cause of diarrhoea in low- and middle-income countries and a leading cause of travellers' diarrhoea.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Mutation biology"

Links: [{"title":"Mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation"},{"title":"Mutant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutant"},{"title":"Point mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Point_mutation"},{"title":"De novo mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_novo_mutation"},{"title":"Neutral mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neutral_mutation"},{"title":"Mutation accumulation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation_accumulation_theory"},{"title":"Frameshift mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frameshift_mutation"},{"title":"Silent mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silent_mutation"},{"title":"Mutation (evolutionary algorithm) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation_(evolutionary_algorithm)"},{"title":"Suppressor mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suppressor_mutation"}]

## Mutation in Biology

In biology, a mutation is an alteration in the nucleic acid sequence of the genome of an organism, virus, or extrachromosomal DNA.

### Origin of Mutations

Mutations result from errors during DNA or viral replication, mitosis, or meiosis or other types of damage to DNA (such as pyrimidine dimers caused by exposure to ultraviolet radiation), which then may undergo error-prone repair, cause an error during other forms of repair, or cause an error during replication.(no content)Mutations may also result from substitution, insertion or deletion of segments of DNA due to mobile genetic elements.

### Effects of Mutations

Mutations may or may not produce detectable changes in the observable characteristics (phenotype) of an organism.(no content)The effect of a mutation on protein sequence depends in part on where in the genome it occurs, especially whether it is in a coding or non-coding region. Mutations in the non-coding regulatory sequences of a gene, such as promoters, enhancers, and silencers, can alter levels of gene expression, but are less likely to alter the protein sequence.

### Biological Significance

Mutations play a part in both normal and abnormal biological processes including: evolution, cancer, and the development of the immune system, including junctional diversity.

### Distinction from DNA Damage

In contrast to a DNA damage, a mutation is an alteration of the base sequence of the DNA. Ordinarily, a mutation cannot be recognized by enzymes once the base change is present in both DNA strands, and thus a mutation is not ordinarily repaired.

## Search Results for "Adaptive Landscape Evolution"

I found comprehensive information about adaptive landscape evolution. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Core Concept

In evolutionary biology, fitness landscapes or adaptive landscapes are used to visualize the relationship between genotypes and reproductive success.(no content)The fitness landscape is not static in time but dependent on the changing environment and evolution of other genes, and is more of a seascape, further affecting how separated adaptive peaks can actually be.

### Evolution of the Concept

In Simpson's model, the landscape could vary through time, while in Wright's model, the landscape was static.(no content)The concept has been formalized in statistical-physical models that analyse time-dependent selection gradients, adaptive fluxes, and the movement of peaks in a changing environment, with fitness seascapes generalizing traditional fitness landscapes by incorporating non-stationary selection.

### Adaptive vs. Fitness Landscapes

The adaptive landscape is constructed assuming that both density and frequency-dependent selection is involved, and the shape of the adaptive landscape can change drastically in response to even small changes in strategies and densities.(no content)The flexibility of adaptive landscapes provide several ways for natural selection to cross valleys and occupy multiple peaks without having to make large changes in their strategies.

### Population Movement

If a given species is able to evolve, it will, over time, "climb" the adaptive landscape toward a fitness peak through gradual changes in its mean phenotype.

Web search results for query: "Gene knockout"

Links: [{"title":"Gene knockout - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_knockout"},{"title":"Conditional gene knockout - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conditional_gene_knockout"},{"title":"Gene knock-in - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_knock-in"},{"title":"Knockout mouse - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knockout_mouse"},{"title":"Gene knockdown - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_knockdown"},{"title":"DMRT1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DMRT1"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk%3AGene_knockout"},{"title":"Gene silencing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_silencing"},{"title":"Martin Hrabě de Angelis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Hrab%C4%95_de_Angelis"},{"title":"Knockout moss - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knockout_moss"}]

## Gene Knockout Overview

Gene knockouts (also known as gene deletion or gene inactivation) are a widely used genetic engineering technique that involves the targeted removal or inactivation of a specific gene within an organism's genome.(no content)This can be done through a variety of methods, including homologous recombination, CRISPR-Cas9, and TALENs.

### Key Applications

One of the main advantages of gene knockouts is that they allow researchers to study the function of a specific gene in vivo, and to understand the role of the gene in normal development and physiology as well as in the pathology of diseases. By studying the phenotype of the organism with the knocked out gene, researchers can gain insights into the biological processes that the gene is involved in.(no content)Gene knockouts have been widely used in many different organisms, including bacteria, yeast, fruit flies, zebrafish, and mice. In mice, gene knockouts are commonly used to study the function of specific genes in development, physiology, and cancer research.

### Types of Gene Knockouts

There are two main types of gene knockouts: complete and conditional. A complete gene knockout permanently inactivates the gene, while a conditional gene knockout allows for the gene to be turned off and on at specific times or in specific tissues.

### History and Recognition

The first recorded knockout mouse was created by Mario R. Capecchi, Martin Evans, and Oliver Smithies in 1989, for which they were awarded the 2007 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.

### Limitations

Gene knockouts also have some limitations. For example, the loss of a single gene may not fully mimic the effects of a genetic disorder, and the knockouts may have unintended effects on other genes or pathways.

Web search results for query: "Transposon molecular biology"

Links: [{"title":"Transposable element - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposable_element"},{"title":"DNA transposon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DNA_transposon"},{"title":"Transposase - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposase"},{"title":"Tn3 transposon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tn3_transposon"},{"title":"Conservative transposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservative_transposition"},{"title":"Horizontal gene transfer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horizontal_gene_transfer"},{"title":"Transposon mutagenesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposon_mutagenesis"},{"title":"Transposon sequencing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposon_sequencing"},{"title":"Transposons as a genetic tool - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposons_as_a_genetic_tool"},{"title":"Retrotransposon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retrotransposon"}]

I've found comprehensive information about transposons in molecular biology. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Definition and Basic Concept

A transposable element (TE), also transposon, or jumping gene, is a type of mobile genetic element, a nucleic acid sequence in DNA that can change its position within a genome.

## Classification

Transposons are divided into two main classes based on their transposition mechanisms:

- **Class I (Retrotransposons):** Retrotransposons (also called Class I transposable elements) are mobile elements which move in the host genome by converting their transcribed RNA into DNA through reverse transcription.

- **Class II (DNA Transposons):** They are class II transposable elements (TEs) that move through a DNA intermediate, as opposed to class I TEs, retrotransposons, that move through an RNA intermediate.

## Transposition Mechanisms

There are three main classifications for movement for DNA transposons: "cut and paste," "rolling circle" (Helitrons), and "self-synthesizing" (Polintons).(no content)The transposase makes a staggered cut at the target site producing sticky ends, cuts out the DNA transposon and ligates it into the target site.

## Autonomous vs. Non-Autonomous Elements

Autonomous TEs can move by themselves, whereas non-autonomous TEs require the presence of another TE to move. This is often because dependent TEs lack transposase (for Class II) or reverse transcriptase (for Class I).

## Applications and Tools

They can be harnessed as a genetic tool for the analysis of gene and protein function.(no content)The Sleeping Beauty transposon system (SBTS) is the first successful non-viral vector for incorporation of a gene cassette into a vertebrate genome.

## Historical Significance

The discovery of mobile genetic elements earned Barbara McClintock a Nobel Prize in 1983.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

- **Class I (Retrotransposons):** Retrotransposons (also called Class I transposable elements) are mobile elements which move in the host genome by converting their transcribed RNA into DNA through reverse transcription.

- **Class II (DNA Transposons):** They are class II transposable elements (TEs) that move through a DNA intermediate, as opposed to class I TEs, retrotransposons, that move through an RNA intermediate.

## Transposition Mechanisms

There are three main classifications for movement for DNA transposons: "cut and paste," "rolling circle" (Helitrons), and "self-synthesizing" (Polintons).(no content)The transposase makes a staggered cut at the target site producing sticky ends, cuts out the DNA transposon and ligates it into the target site.

## Autonomous vs. Non-Autonomous Elements

Autonomous TEs can move by themselves, whereas non-autonomous TEs require the presence of another TE to move. This is often because dependent TEs lack transposase (for Class II) or reverse transcriptase (for Class I).

## Applications and Tools

They can be harnessed as a genetic tool for the analysis of gene and protein function.(no content)The Sleeping Beauty transposon system (SBTS) is the first successful non-viral vector for incorporation of a gene cassette into a vertebrate genome.

## Historical Significance

The discovery of mobile genetic elements earned Barbara McClintock a Nobel Prize in 1983.

message_text:
## Analysis Complete! ✅

I have successfully analyzed the paper "Quantifying the local adaptive landscape of a nascent bacterial community" and created the structured triples output.

### Summary:

**Paper Classification:** **Contribution**
- The paper proposes novel methodology (genome-wide barcoded transposon libraries) to measure fitness effects and provides new empirical findings about adaptive landscapes in bacterial communities.

**Key Entities Identified (8 triples):**

1. **Fitness landscape** (concept) - Used to analyze how fitness effects vary across genetic backgrounds
2. **Mutation** (concept) - Core entity measuring fitness effects of all possible mutations
3. **Epistasis** (concept) - Analyzes how epistatic effects combine with ecological effects
4. **Escherichia coli** (artifact) - The organism from the Long-Term Evolution Experiment
5. **Transposable element** (tool) - **PROPOSED** as novel methodology with genome-wide barcoding
6. **Gene knockout** (method) - Used to measure invasion fitness effects
7. **Fitness (biology)** (concept) - Quantifies fitness effects across conditions
8. **Adaptation** (concept) - Analyzes evolutionary adaptation dynamics

**Validation Result:** ✅ All validation checks passed
- Paper type correctly classified as contribution
- All 8 triples have valid Wikipedia URLs
- Entity types properly categorized (5 concepts, 1 artifact, 1 tool, 1 method)
- At least 1 "proposes" relation present (required for contribution papers)
- At least 1 "uses" relation present (required for all papers)

Sources:
- [Fitness landscape](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_landscape)
- [Mutation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation)
- [Epistasis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistasis)
- [Escherichia coli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escherichia_coli)
- [Transposable element](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposable_element)
- [Gene knockout](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_knockout)
- [Fitness (biology)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_(biology))
- [Adaptation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptation)
